title: Reading, writing, and math self-concept in elementary school children: influence of dimensional comparison processes
abstract: The internal/external (I/E) frame of reference model (Marsh, Am Educ Res J 23:129-149, 1986) conceptualizes students' self-concepts as being formed by dimensional as well as social comparison processes. In the present study, the I/E model was tested and extended in a sample of elementary school children. Core academic skills of reading, writing, and math were related to corresponding and non-corresponding self-concept facets to determine the onset of dimensional contrast effects. School achievement and domainspecific academic self-concepts of 1,114 students from grades 1 to 3 were assessed. Negative paths were found for math achievement on reading self-concept and for reading achievement on math self-concept in the third grade. Math achievement was not associated negatively with writing self-concept. Positive influences were found within the verbal domain for writing achievement on reading self-concept from grade 1 onward. The results suggest a broad interpretation of the I/E model in which contrast as well as assimilation effects are possible. Factors influencing the dimensional comparison processes are discussed. Keywords Self-concept. I/E model. Elementary school. Writing. Spelling In the past decades, research on children's academic self-concept focused on its development and structure as well as on its relation to academic achievement (

abstract.text: The internal/external (I/E) frame of reference model (Marsh, Am Educ Res J 23:129-149, 1986) conceptualizes students' self-concepts as being formed by dimensional as well as social comparison processes. In the present study, the I/E model was tested and extended in a sample of elementary school children. Core academic skills of reading, writing, and math were related to corresponding and non-corresponding self-concept facets to determine the onset of dimensional contrast effects. School achievement and domainspecific academic self-concepts of 1,114 students from grades 1 to 3 were assessed. Negative paths were found for math achievement on reading self-concept and for reading achievement on math self-concept in the third grade. Math achievement was not associated negatively with writing self-concept. Positive influences were found within the verbal domain for writing achievement on reading self-concept from grade 1 onward. The results suggest a broad interpretation of the I/E model in which contrast as well as assimilation effects are possible. Factors influencing the dimensional comparison processes are discussed. Keywords Self-concept. I/E model. Elementary school. Writing. Spelling In the past decades, research on children's academic self-concept focused on its development and structure as well as on its relation to academic achievement (

body_text.text: Marsh and colleagues (Marsh 1986; Marsh et al. 1988) . Studies that focused mainly on secondary school students have demonstrated the multidimensional nature of academic self-concept and the so-called dimensional comparison effects between various self-concept facets (Möller and Köller 2001 ; see also Marsh and Hau 2004; Möller et al. 2006b ). Regarding elementary school education, however, validations of the I/E model are sparse and the impact of dimensional comparisons on self-concept development remains unclear. Surprisingly, former investigations have focused on reading and math only, although learning to write-especially to spell-is also one of the major goals during the elementary school years. As a consequence, the influence of writing 1 achievement on the corresponding and non-corresponding self-concepts is still unknown.

Given the fact that the acquisition of the cultural techniques of reading, writing, and math are the key academic objectives in elementary school curricula, it is important to consider these basic skills when examining the development of children's multifaceted academic selfconcept, especially the emergence of dimensional comparison processes. The present study addresses three unresolved issues: (1) the generalizability of the academic self-concept and I/E model to the area of writing, (2) the onset of dimensional comparisons between the verbal and math domains within the first 3 years of elementary school, and (3) the relationship between achievement and self-concept within the verbal domain.

Academic self-concepts are mental representations of one's own capabilities in academic domains and school subjects (Valentine et al. 2004) . They are based on experiences in achievement situations and the respective interpretations. Therefore, self-concepts are shaped by interactions with the environment and significant others (Shavelson et al. 1976) . A number of empirical findings revealing a positive relation between self-concept and academic achievement highlight the concept's theoretical and practical importance (Guay et al. 2010; Helmke and van Aken 1995; Marsh and Craven 2006) . High levels of academic self-concept are associated with high self-efficacy (Bong and Skaalvik 2003) , cognitive and emotional engagement in school (Helmke 1999 ), a pronounced learning and achievement motivation, as well as academic effort (Guay et al. 2010 ). Because academic self-concept is both a cause and an effect of academic achievement (see reciprocal effect model; Marsh and Craven 2006) , self-concept enhancement is of major concern in education and child development settings (Marsh 2007) .

Since the self-concept is considered an important individual resource, discussions on theoretical framing increased noticeably during the last decades (Brunner et al. 2010; Byrne 1996; Marsh 1990b) . Shavelson et al. (1976) presented an influential multifaceted and hierarchically structured model of self-concepts, which had a fundamental impact on further self-concept research. The model postulates a general self-concept at the apex of the self-concept hierarchy, which is subdivided into a nonacademic and an academic component (partitioned into various subjectspecific subdomains, e.g., English and mathematics). While the claim for multidimensionality was strongly supported, the model's central assumption that the self-concepts in particular academic areas are highly correlated and form a higher-order academic self-concept was not substantiated (Marsh et al. 1988; Marsh 1989 Marsh , 1990b Marsh and Shavelson 1985) . However, Marsh (1989) demonstrated that by the age of about 10 years, children's math and verbal self-concepts were basically uncorrelated. Pursuant to these findings, Marsh (1986) developed the I/E model.

The I/E model describes two key sources of information (social and dimensional) relevant for the constitution of subject-specific ability self-concepts. The interindividual or social comparison (external frame of reference) is defined by students' self-perceptions of their own achievements compared to the perceived achievements of other students (Marsh et al. 1988 ). Because achievements in school subjects are positively correlated, it seems reasonable to assume that domain-specific self-concepts are also positively correlated. Empirically, no such positive relation between the math and English self-concept was found (Marsh 1986 ). Marsh argues that students compare their performance in one school subject intra-individually with their performance in other subjects. This dimensional comparison (Möller and Köller 2001) builds the internal frame of reference and can lead to a contrast effect: achievement in one subject has a negative effect on the self-concept in other subjects and incrementally increases the differences between various self-concept domains. Thus, students perceive math and verbal achievement as being more different than they actually are.

Because achievement estimation in one domain depends on the perceived achievement in the other domain, different self-concepts can be observed among students with the same achievement level in one domain. For example students A and B have the same grade in math but different grades in German (student A has a higher grade compared to math, student B has a lower grade). Thus, student B will demonstrate a higher math self-concept compared to student A (Möller et al. 2009) . Furthermore, comparison processes lead to an overestimation of one's own strengths and an underestimation of one's intra-individually weaker domain. However, because downward comparisons are stronger than upward dimensional comparisons, dimensional comparison processes in general contribute to an increase in students' academic self-concept (Pohlmann and Möller 2009) .

In most cases, research regarding the I/E model has focused on secondary school students (Marsh 1986 (Marsh , 1990c Möller and Köller 2001; Möller et al. 2006b; Skaalvik and Rankin 1992) . Regarding young elementary school children, validations of the I/E model are rather sparse (Faber 1992; Möller et al. 2009 Möller et al. , 2011a . However, at this stage of development, children typically claim that they are among the "best in their class" as they have difficulties in differentiating between actual and desired attributes and in using information from social comparisons adequately (Harter 1999) . Therefore, their self-evaluations are likely to be very positive but, unfortunately, also unrealistic (Eccles et al. 1993; Helmke 1999) . Certainly, elementary school children are able to report their self-perceptions and to discriminate between various facets of selfconcept from first grade onward (Marsh et al. 1991 (Marsh et al. , 2002 . Accordingly, children realize that they have relative strengths and weaknesses across different domains . However, due to these dimensional comparisons, the multiple dimensions of self-concept become more differentiated. Although some studies have explored the development of academic self-concepts in elementary school-aged children (Chapman and Tunmer 1997; Guay et al. 2003; Helmke and van Aken 1995; Marsh et al. 1991 , it remains an open question from which grade onward dimensional comparison effects exist. Findings from third and fourth grade students indicate that dimensional effects may already exist at the end of elementary school, but no information is available so far about the first years of elementary school (Faber 1992; Möller et al. 2009 Möller et al. , 2011a .
body_text.section: Internal/external frame of reference model in elementary school children

body_text.text: Most of the studies assessing self-concept in elementary school children focus on reading and math (e.g., Self-Description Questionnaire I; Marsh 1990a), whereas the development of the writing self-concept has been neglected so far. Hence, it is still unclear how reading and writing self-concepts as well as math and writing self-concepts are related to each other and to corresponding and non-corresponding achievements. The examination of the writing self-concept is important because the acquisition of writing skills-especially spelling-is a central educational task in the elementary school curriculum and is considered highly important for a child's academic career (Bos et al. 2007) . Consequently, writing has to be incorporated into investigations that focus on elementary school children's academic self-concept, thus extending the classical I/E model.
body_text.section: Internal/external frame of reference model in elementary school children

body_text.text: The current study had three major objectives: The first goal was to investigate self-concept and achievement regarding reading, writing, and math in early elementary school years to extend the I/E model. These skills are central to the early school education. Thus, we assume that these skills represent salient sources of information for intra-individual comparison processes. More precisely, we expect to find three distinct self-concept factors. The second goal was to analyze the I/E model in the first 3 years of elementary school to determine the onset of the dimensional effects predicted by the model. Specifically, we examined the hypothesis provided by Harter (1999) that a greater differentiation among self-perceptions emerges at about 8 years of age. The third goal was to analyze the relationship of achievement indicators and self-concept factors within the verbal domain. Therefore, we examined the influence of reading achievement on writing selfconcept and writing achievement on reading self-concept. Specifically, we directly addressed the impact these two skills have on the corresponding and non-corresponding self-concept facets. Because dimensional comparisons can also lead to assimilation effects (Möller and Marsh 2013) and reading and writing are taught simultaneously in the subject German and are closely related and influenced by each other (Abbott et al. 2010) , we predicted positive paths for reading achievement on writing self-concept as well as for writing achievement on reading self-concept.

In total, the sample consisted of 1,114 students from grade 1 (n=410; 52.9 % male; M age =6.85 years, SD=0.47 years), grade 2 (n=384; 47.4 % male; M age =7.92 years, SD=0.39 years), and grade 3 (n=320; 50.3 % male; M age =8.66 years, SD=0.62 years). The participants attended 1 of 72 elementary schools in the federal states of Hessen and Baden-Württemberg, Germany (31/23/18 classes in grades 1/2/3; class size grades 1/2/3: M=13.23/16.70/17.78, SD=6.05/5.62/4.21). All instruments were administered by trained university students in the classroom during regular school lessons in the last quarter of the academic year. The cross-sectional data collection took part on a voluntary basis after permissions were obtained from the parents.

In order to assess academic self-concept, we constructed a new instrument suitable for elementary school children. Our self-concept measure was developed following the Self-Description Questionnaire (SDQ; Marsh 1990a) and the self-concept scales of the German LOGIK study (Helmke and van Aken 1995) . For reading, writing, and math, we used responses to six positively worded items on a seven-point Likert-type scale (ranging from 1=very poor to 7=very good, with higher values indicating higher self-concepts). The points of the scale were illustrated via small stick figures (instead of digits) representing classmates. The children's task was to label one of the stick figures representing their own capabilities. In each scale, one of the six items required explicit social comparison processes (e.g., "In reading, I am the worst/best"). The items reflected evaluative ("In reading, I am not gifted/very gifted") as well as emotional ("Reading is no fun/a lot of fun") beliefs about one's academic achievement (Burnett 1994) . For group administration purposes, each child was given a copy of the self-concept questionnaire. The experimenter read the instructions aloud, presented two sample items, and then answered questions before presenting the questionnaire. In grades 1 and 2, every single item was read aloud to the students.

Measures of school performance were administered by standardized school achievement tests, based on the curriculum representative for all German states. Performance in reading was assessed by ELFE 1-6 ("Ein Leseverständnistest für Erst-bis Sechstklässler"; Lenhard and Schneider 2006) or WLLP-R ("Würzburger Leise-Leseprobe-Revision"; Schneider et al. 2011). The WLLP-R, where children are required to map images to words (120 items; parallel test reliability r AB =0.87 for grade 1 and 0.92 for grade 2), was used in grades 1 and 2. In the reading test ELFE 1-6, which was employed in grades 2 and 3, children had to map words to images (72 items; Cronbach's alpha=0.97). Writing performance was measured by a spelling test "Deutscher Rechtschreibtest für das erste und zweite Schuljahr" (DERET 1-2+; Stock and Schneider 2008a) as well as by "Deutscher Rechtschreibtest für das dritte und vierte Schuljahr" (DERET 3-4+; Stock and Schneider 2008b) . Children are asked to write a dictation consisting of 29 words in grade 1, 52 words in grade 2, and 79 words in grade 3 (Cronbach's alpha=0.90 to 0.92).

To test mathematical achievement, the series of "Deutsche Mathematiktest für erste/ zweite/dritte Klassen" (DEMAT 1+, Krajewski et al. 2002 ; DEMAT 2+, Krajewski et al. 2004; DEMAT 3+, Roick et al. 2004) or "Diagnostisches Inventar zu Rechenfertigkeiten im Grundschulalter" (DIRG; Grube et al. 2010) were used. The DEMAT (Cronbach's alpha=0.83 to 0.93) investigates competencies in arithmetic, applied mathematics, and geometry. The DIRG (Cronbach's alpha=0.93) was used in grades 1 and 2; it only investigates competencies in arithmetic.

First, we applied a multiple-group confirmatory factor analysis (CFA). The model fit of a first-order model with three latent factors (reading, writing, and math self-concepts) was compared to a first-order model with only two latent factors where reading and writing items were forced to load on the same factor. The goal of these analyses was to test whether or not the three-factor model adequately fits the data, which is a precondition to evaluating the extended I/E model. Instead of constructing item parcels, we used all items to obtain indicators of the latent self-concept factors. Model identification was achieved by fixing one unstandardized factor loading of each factor to 1. All other model parameters were freely estimated. To check whether the self-concept instrument measures the self-concept in all three age groups in a comparable way, factor loadings were set as equal across groups (metric invariance).

In a second step, latent self-concept factors were set in relation to manifest achievement indicators in a structural equation model (SEM). Regression paths were evaluated from every achievement indicator to every self-concept factor, while correlations between achievement indicators on one hand and correlations between the residual terms of the self-concept factors on the other hand were permitted. After establishing measurement invariance for the extended I/E model by accepting the model with metric equivalence, we compared regression weights in order to examine age-related differences in achievement self-concept relations.

In our analyses, free model parameters were estimated using the full information maximum likelihood estimator "MLR" as implemented in Mplus 6.1 (Muthén and Muthén 1998-2010) . To evaluate the goodness of fit for the CFA and SEM, we used the chi-square test statistic. Because this statistic is known to be highly sensitive to sample size, we also used several commonly recommended descriptive measures of model fit (Hu and Bentler 1998) : the standardized root mean squared residual (SRMR) and the root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA) as well as the comparative fit index (CFI). Models were evaluated as fitting well when the baseline fit indices (SRMR and RMSEA) were <0.08 and the incremental fit index (CFI) was 0.95 or larger. Since this is important for nested model comparisons, we also examined the chi-square difference test. Furthermore, we applied the Akaike information criterion (AIC), which combines the chi-square goodness-of-fit statistic with the corresponding number of degrees of freedom.

To test whether the regression paths from achievement indicators on self-concept factors differed between the three grade levels, these paths were constrained to be equal across groups. Significant differences in the path are reflected in a significant change in model fit of the restrictive model in comparison to the model without such a constraint. Changes in model fit were obtained with the Satorra-Bentler Scaled Chi-Square Difference (TRd), which has a scaling correction to better approximate chi-square with non-normal data when using the MLR estimation method in Mplus (Satorra and Bentler 2001) . Table 1 shows the correlations, means, standard deviations, and reliability scores for achievement indicators and self-concept measures. Reliability scores of the academic self-concept measures ranged between 0.80 and 0.93, indicating good internal consistency. Analysis of reliability also revealed that one item of writing self-concept as well as one item of math selfconcept led to a reduction of internal consistency. Consequently, these two items were excluded from further analysis.
body_text.section: Tests of invariance across different age cohorts

body_text.text: As presented in Table 1 , the correlations between reading and writing self-concepts were positive in all grades, ranging from r=0.46 to r=0.52. The correlation between reading selfconcept and math self-concept was also significantly positive for grade 1 (r=0.20) and 2 (r=0.13), but not for grade 3 (r=0.03). A similar pattern was found for the correlation between writing selfconcept and math self-concept. Here, for all grade levels, a significant positive correlation was found, which slightly decreases with grade level (from r=0.25 to r=0.17). Overall, the correlations between the self-concept scores were substantially smaller than correlations between the corresponding achievement indicators.

Empirical evidence for three distinct facets of academic self-concept: results of confirmatory factor analyses The confirmation of the three-factor structure of academic self-concept constitutes a precondition for the examination of the extended I/E model. Therefore, a CFA was carried out where each measured variable was allowed to load only on the factor that it was meant to measure. Correlations between the three latent factors were freely estimated. Correlations between the residual variances of items assessing emotional beliefs about one's academic achievement within one self-concept factor were allowed (e.g., "Reading is no fun/a lot of fun" with "I like to read, not at all/very much so"). This model provided a good fit to the data: χ 2 (294)=557.17, p<0.001, CFI=0.957, RMSEA=0.049, SRMR=0.056, AIC=58,693.22. The items estimated their associated factors with standardized regression weights in the order of magnitude from 0.49 to 0.91 (see Table 3 in the Appendix). A further multigroup analysis tested the invariance of the factor loadings across different grades (grade 1 vs. grade 2 vs. grade 3). Setting all factor loadings as invariant revealed a similar fit: χ 2 (320)=593.064, p<0.001; CFI=0.955, RMSEA=0.048, SRMR=0.065, AIC=58,688.70 and led to no significant change in chi-square difference statistic TRd=35.78, p>0.05, indicating that the three factors were similar across the three grade levels. In contrast, the model with only two factors, in which the items of reading and writing were loading on one factor, showed a significantly poorer and inacceptable fit: χ 2 (304)=1,176.10, p<0.001, CFI=0.857, RMSEA=0.088, SRMR=0.091, AIC=59,513.63.
Relating academic achievement to academic self-concept in different domains: findings from path analysis

In a further step of our analyses, we explored how achievement in the three different domains affects the three self-concept facets. Table 2 presents the model fit of the extended I/E model. The path coefficients and the correlations for the three different grade levels of the standardized solution are presented in Fig. 1 . Path coefficients from all achievement indicators to the corresponding self-concepts were positive and significant. The weakest path was found for writing in grade 1 (0.17), while the strongest path was found for math in grade 3 (0.58).

Interestingly, the patterns of results within the verbal domain are inconsistent. While writing achievement had a positive influence on reading self-concept at all three grade levels, a comparable impact of reading achievement on writing self-concept was not found. The I/E model's central assumption that achievement in one domain (e.g., verbal) negatively influences self-concept in the other domain (e.g., math) was not fully confirmed. Math achievement showed a significant negative influence on reading self-concept in grade 3 (−0.18), whereas no significant negative path coefficient was found for writing self-concept. Similar results were found regarding the influence of verbal achievement on math self-concept. Writing achievement had no significant negative influence on math self-concept, whereas reading achievement was found to have a negative influence on math self-concept in grade 3. All χ 2 values were statistically significant. For model M3 to M9, the paths were equated in each case across the three age groups (the paths of the variables specified in parentheses). For M8 to M11, paths were equated across constructs (the paths of the variables specified in parentheses). The ChiDiff (TRΔχ 2 ) statistics of M3 to M5 is indicated in each case compared to M2 with Satorra-Bentler Scaled Chi-Square Difference CFI comparative fit index, NFI normed fit index, RMSEA root mean square error of approximation, SRMR root mean squared residual, AIC Akaike information criterion a Factor loadings are constrained to be invariant (equal) across age groups

To evaluate grade-related differences in the achievement self-concept relation, the regression paths from achievement indicators to self-concept facets were set equal across the grade levels and the model fit of these restrictive models were compared to model 2 (M2). Fit indices of these analyses are presented in Table 2 . Equating the paths from achievement indicators to corresponding self-concepts across the grades (M3 to M5) led to a significant change in chi-square difference statistic (see Table 2 ). Thus, the positive influences were significantly stronger at higher grade levels. Although a significant negative path from reading achievement to math self-concept as well as from math achievement to reading self-concept was only observable in grade 3, equating these paths led to an insignificant change in chi-square difference statistic (see M6 and M7).
body_text.section: Invariance of path coefficients across grade levels

body_text.text: Additional analyses were carried out to examine the effects of achievement indicators on corresponding and non-corresponding self-concept facets. This was done by simultaneously setting different paths to be equal across domains at all grade levels. In model 8, the path coefficients for reading achievement on writing self-concept were constrained to be equal to the path coefficients of writing achievement on reading self-concept. These constraints provided a much poorer fit, indicating that the influence of reading achievement on writing self-concept is not identical to the influence of writing achievement on reading self-concept. Although reading achievement had a significantly larger effect on reading self-concept than writing achievement (M9), no significant change in model fit was found when constraining the path of writing achievement on writing self-concept and the path of writing achievement on reading self-concept to be equal (M10). This indicates that writing achievement had a comparable influence on reading and writing self-concepts.
body_text.section: Invariance of path coefficients across domains

body_text.text: In this study we accomplished three major goals: First, we extended the academic selfconcept and the I/E model to the self-concept of writing. Second, we examined from which grade onward dimensional contrast effects occur. Third, we investigated the relationships between achievement and self-concept factors within the verbal domain.

Although the reading and writing self-concepts were substantially correlated, they were found to be separate constructs. The results strongly supported the three-factor solution. With respect to the I/E model in elementary school students, there were three main findings: First, we found significant associations between achievement indicators and corresponding self-concept facets at all grade levels. The magnitude of these associations increased with grade level. Second, considering internal frames of reference, math achievement was negatively associated with reading self-concept and reading achievement was negatively associated with math self-concept in grade 3. However, no significant negative associations were found between writing and math (writing achievement on math self-concept and math achievement on writing self-concept). Third, a positive influence of writing achievement on reading self-concept was found irrespective of grade level.

The results of the CFA showed three distinct self-concept facets specific to each achievement domain. Moreover, the factor structure was relatively robust and generalizable across elementary school age (i.e., factor loadings were found to be invariant across grade levels). This finding implies that, from first grade onward, students can successfully discriminate between these domains. Interestingly, the correlation between reading and writing selfconcept remains rather stable across the three grade levels and approximately corresponds to the relationship between reading and writing performance. With regard to the self-concept measurement, the question arises as to whether the correlation between reading and writing self-concepts would have been weaker if items had been used which enforce the internal comparison process (ipsative measurement; Marsh and Yeung 2001) .
body_text.section: Dimensionality of academic self-concept and relation to corresponding achievement

body_text.text: The SEM analyses confirmed central assumptions of the I/E model. In line with previous findings, domain-specific achievement was positively related to self-concept in the corresponding domain (Brunner et al. 2008; Marsh and Yeung 2001; Möller et al. 2006b) . Consistent with other studies on age-related differences in the self-concept achievement relation, the associations were stronger in higher grades (Eccles et al. 1993; Helmke 1999; Marsh et al. 1991 ). In particular, the impact of writing achievement on writing selfconcept was relatively small in grade 1. Although alternative interpretations are possible, we think that this is partly due to first graders not being familiar with writing, especially with spelling. While children are somehow already confronted with reading and math in kindergarten (e.g., math or letter games), they usually do not become familiar with writing before elementary school. However, third graders seem to have acquired a selfperception of their writing capability that is as realistic and accurate as their reading and math self-concepts.
body_text.section: Dimensionality of academic self-concept and relation to corresponding achievement

body_text.text: One of our central objectives was to determine from which grade onward dimensional contrast effects occur between the verbal and math domains. Significant negative paths between reading and math were not found before grade 3, although the significance level at grade 2 was only marginally missed. Therefore, we assume that children use their selfperceived accomplishments in one academic area as basis for forming their self-concepts in another academic area in the course of grade 3. Although children can compare the different abilities earlier on, the contrasting comparisons seem to start around this age. This interpretation is consistent with Harter's (1999) suggestion that greater differentiation among selfperceptions occurs at about 8 years of age. Hence, our results are compatible with the assumption of a gradual developmental trend of increasing differentiation between math and verbal self-concepts during elementary school years (Marsh et al. 1991) . Although a number of factors might contribute to this phenomenon, the tradition in German elementary schools to begin grading at the end of grade 2 may trigger the effectiveness of dimensional comparisons, as students from this point in time not only receive information about the capabilities of their classmates, but also about their own capabilities in the different domains. However, these dimensional comparison processes seem to be limited to the relationship between reading and math. Contrary to the prediction of the I/E model, we did not find a significant negative impact of writing achievement on math self-concept or of math achievement on writing self-concept. Thus, children seem to disregard their perceived writing achievement when judging their math skills. Hence, children at this stage of development might particularly perceive reading rather than writing as the core verbal domain. In kindergarten, reading and math already appear as different domains (e.g., reading corner, number games); hence, the specificity of students' capability beliefs (Möller et al. 2006a) may refer more strongly to these domains. The acquisition of writing, however, is not achieved before elementary school, with the consequence that this domain perhaps plays a minor role in dimensional comparison processes.
body_text.section: Dimensional influences between the verbal and math domain

body_text.text: From a more general perspective, the missing contrast effect between math and writing seems to contradict the I/E model at first glance. This is due to the fact that the I/E model was mainly used to explain contrast effects, although assimilation effects are also possible in dimensional comparisons (Möller and Marsh 2013) . However, the question of whether students really contrast different skills and school subjects seems to be influenced by various factors and contextual conditions. For example, the number of domains and subjects, which have to be compared, seem to affect dimensional comparison processes (Brunner et al. 2010) . When a limited number of academic domains is considered, the empirical relations correspond exactly to what was predicted by the I/E model (e.g., Marsh et al. 1988) . However, when a broader spectrum of school subjects is considered, the verbal and math domains are mostly substantively correlated (Marsh 1990b) . As a consequence, one could argue that contrast effects might only be found in situations where two significantly different domains are compared. Moreover, as Rost et al. (2004) showed, the contrast effect between the verbal and math domains is stronger the more the student's achievements differ in the corresponding areas. If students achieve identical outcomes in corresponding areas, contrasting dimensional comparison processes are less obvious. This corroborates the view that dimensional contrast effects in self-concepts are less likely in similar domains compared to domains which are per se more distinctive (Dickhäuser 2003) . However, dimensional contrast effects between writing and math cannot be excluded in elementary school. They may be found when only writing and math are compared (Faber 1992) or writing is related in the self-concept test instructions to one language (e.g., German).
body_text.section: Dimensional influences between the verbal and math domain

body_text.text: A further issue addressed in this study refers to the relations of achievement and self-concept facets within the verbal domain. While Marsh and Yeung (2001) found negative associations between different language subjects in secondary school students, no comparable associations were found in the present study. On the contrary, writing achievement even had a significant positive impact on the reading self-concept. Interestingly, this influence was rather similar to the influence of writing achievement on the writing self-concept (model 10). Nevertheless, reading achievement does not seem to contribute to the writing self-concept, as no significant relationship could be observed in this respect. At first glance, this differential pattern of results is somehow surprising, given that reading skill is held to be an important precondition of spelling (Jenkins et al. 2004) . Accordingly, we expected to find a positive path from reading achievement to the writing self-concept. However, differences in reading and spelling achievements might have caused this pattern of results. In German, the grapheme-phoneme correspondence is significantly higher than the phoneme-grapheme correspondence (Landerl and Wimmer 2008) . Therefore, despite the high correlation between reading and spelling, a good reader is not necessarily good at spelling (Bosman and van Orden 1997) . However, good spelling skills require good reading skills (Jenkins et al. 2004) . Consequently, while high levels in spelling skills are associated with rather positive writing and reading self-concepts, high levels of reading achievement are not necessarily associated with strong writing self-concepts.

However, contrast effects between reading and writing cannot be excluded. For example, when students received separate grades for these abilities, dimensional comparisons could increase and contrast effects may be found for students whose achievements differ significantly in these skills. Moreover, like the relationship between the verbal and math domains, the relationship within the verbal domain may be influenced by the format of the selfconcept instrument used. As mentioned previously, the relationship between the self-concept facets of reading and writing may be closer when both are related to a specific language in the test instructions (e.g., German). Moreover, the kind of relationship between reading and writing that would arise when these skills are related to two languages, such as English and German, in test instructions remains an open question. Further studies are thus needed to address the question of whether the relationship between reading and writing is more pronounced within a language or rather between different languages.

A limitation of the present study arises from its cross-sectional design and non-experimental nature. Any causal interpretations, even though based on relevant theories, have, thus, to be treated with caution. In order to analyze effects of achievement indicators on different selfconcept facets and the developmental trajectories of various self-concept facets and their interrelationships, longitudinal data are needed (see Möller et al. 2011b) . Future studies should also include a broader scope of external validity criteria. For example, it would be interesting to investigate which pattern of results emerges when using school grades or differentiated teacher ratings of children's reading, writing, and math achievements. In addition, it would be worthwhile to measure general school aptitudes and general academic self-concept in order to test the nested Marsh/Shavelson model (Brunner et al. 2010 ) with elementary school children.

A second limitation arises from the assessment of writing achievement by a spelling test, which addresses just one component of writing skills. Most studies dealing with writing estimate students corresponding capability by multiple measures like handwriting, composing, and spelling (Graham et al. 2012) . However, spelling is of particularly significance for later school achievement (Bos et al. 2007) , writing education targets spelling in particular, and spelling is closely related to the other components of writing (Berninger et al. 2002; Graham et al. 1997) . Moreover, our findings demonstrated the importance of this writing component for the writing self-concept, as well as the reading self-concept. Nevertheless, multiple achievement measures should be used in a latent variable approach to obtain a broader and more valid estimate of students writing achievement.

A further limitation concerns the self-concept measure realized in this study. First, the wording of items for the three facets of academic self-concept was not completely identical. Second, like other instruments in the field (e.g., SDQ; Marsh 1990a), the self-concept measure used in the present study assesses a broader capability than captured by the achievement indicators. Most achievement tests focus on specific capabilities like, for instance, the number of mistakes in a spelling test, whereas self-concept contains generalized estimations and emotional beliefs about one's own academic achievement in a specific but more general domain (Burnett 1994) . This difference in conceptualization may be especially relevant to the relation of writing self-concept and writing achievement because the latter had been implemented as a spelling test. However, two items of the writing self-concept focus strongly or rather directly on spelling (see Table 3 in the Appendix). Moreover, in the German language, the distinction between writing and spelling is less clear-cut than in English (writing is called "Schreiben," whereas spelling is called "Rechtschreiben").

In sum, the present findings contribute to extending the existing knowledge of academic selfconcept formation during elementary school years. More specifically, the results provide empirical support to conceptualizing distinct self-concept facets with regard to reading, writing, and math, even in elementary school children. Psychometrically, the factor structure was revealed to be relatively robust and generalizable across elementary school years. Thus, the verbal selfconcept appears to be more differentiated than assumed in previous studies with elementary school children. Moreover, the onset of dimensional comparisons as reflected in the dimensional contrast effect was demonstrated to be earlier than has been suggested before. Especially, math and reading achievements are perceived as more differentiated than they actually are.

In the past, the I/E model was construed rather narrowly, mostly to explain contrast effects. However, we suggest a broader interpretation of the I/E model in which contrast as well as assimilation effects are possible (Möller and Marsh 2013) . Our findings, especially the missing contrast effect between math and writing and the positive influence of writing achievement on reading self-concept as well as findings of other studies (e.g., Dickhäuser 2003; Möller et al. 2006b) , support this interpretation. Thus, the I/E model should be supplemented and clarified in this respect: Under which conditions and in which domains can we expect contrast or assimilation effects.

However, based on the present findings as well as those of previous studies, the usage of dimensional comparative information and the occurrence of contrast effects seem to be influenced by a number of factors such as age and cognitive developmental status of students (Harter 1999) , the extent of experience in the different academic domains, the specificity of students' beliefs of their own capability (Möller et al. 2006a) , the actual differences of students' achievement between academic domains (Rost et al. 2004) , and the number (Brunner 2010) and distinctiveness of the domains and subjects which are compared (Dickhäuser 2003) . At least for the elementary school years, the relation between self-concept and achievement seems to lead only to contrast effects when two significantly different domains are compared (e.g., reading and math), with which students are sufficiently familiar.

We thank the Ministry of Culture, Youth, and Sports in Baden-Württemberg for the support of this study as well as all involved investigators, the children, their parents, and teachers for their commitment. Especially, we would like to thank our co-operation partners of the scientific advisory team of the project "school-prepared child" in Würzburg (Frank Niklas, Sandra Schmiedeler, and Wolfgang Schneider), Heidelberg (Eva Randhawa, Isabelle Keppler, Miriam Johnson, and Herman Schöler), and Frankfurt (Katja Krebs, Hanna Wagner). Without their input, planning, and realization of the study, this article could not have been written. Furthermore, we would like to thank Telse Nagler and Ingrid Plath for the comments on this article. All factor loadings were statistically significantly different from zero (p<0.01)
R latent reading self-concept factor, W latent writing self-concept factor, M latent math self-concept factor

In elementary school, writing abilities include particularly spelling, handwriting (typing), and composing(Graham et al. 2012). In the present study, however, writing skills are operationalized through spelling, which is most important for the writing curriculum in German elementary school education.
